pros: Positive environment with good colleagues.
cons: Hours are enrollment sensitive. If there is a drop in enrollment, the newer faculty may have hour cuts.

review_title: Nice place to teach, but Adjuncts get the short-stick due to Full-Timers controlling the Union.
job_title: Adjunct Professor in New Suffolk, NY
pros: Nice place to teach. Great campuses & wonderful students.
cons: Unfortunately, the Full-Time faculty controls the "union" and Adjunct faculty gets screwed repeatedly. When I first started teaching there (many years ago), all Adjuncts got the same benefits (such as TIAA-CREF contributions) and had the same promotion criteria (such as number of hours taught, etc.) as Full-Timers. However, that changed when the Union took over and completely removed the benefits, while doubling the promotion criteria for Adjuncts. Worst of all, when a Full-Timer's class is cancelled or under-enrolled, they can "bump" more-qualified Adjuncts (and the students suffer!)

review_title: Pleasant place to work for adjuncts, but currently unstable prospects (COVID)
pros: Friendly, helpful colleagues. Students vary a great deal in skills but generally have good attitudes. As adjunct salaries go, at least average for this high-cost area (which means low!)
cons: With COVID, uncertain and declining enrollments. Even adjuncts with intermediate seniority may be bypassed for courses. No medical benefits whatever, but this is common with adjunct positions.

pros: I met some wonderful people while working within the college community staff. Two in particular.   One will be my life friend and confidante that I was able too share my experiences. Another a head departmental Dean of my career choice in the field of EMS services. Another vitally important aspect was the skills I attained from a unlikely job position as a carrier. I was able too gain a skill set never attempted before and thrived. Lastly I was able too network before my hired role position providing me the opportunity of acclamation too the campus community and my various assigned route locations.
cons: The downside would consist of poor pay for assigned duties performed. Insufficient access too all amenities of the Union except one. That being universal pay increases throughout college community. Grievances handled improperly at least to my opinion when addressed by compliant. Unwarranted profiling of specific ethnicities on the campus including workers like myself.

pros: Great place to work, great environment.
cons: None to mention at this time

review_title: Diverse Student Body; Great Faculty Colleagues
pros: We educate students of all backgrounds, ages, and ability levels.
cons: For many adjuncts, the work is only part-time and you may have to work at other colleges to supplement.

pros: friendly staff and good environment
cons: not the best pay you can find

pros: Excellent compensation by hour. Can be promoted even though part time.
cons: Nit able to get full time job there yet

review_title: Overall a great place to work
pros: I enjoy working with community college students.  Many are first generation college students and others are adults coming back to get a degree.  Our students have a lot of life challenges and it is great to see the succeed.   There are also a lot of interesting events going on and for the most part, the other faculty are great.  We have a great union and the benefits and work year are good.
cons: Like most public colleges you have no navigate the bureaucracy and there are a lot of unnecessary rules and regulations.   Like nearly all public colleges, we are underfunded are always trying to do more with less.  Unfortunately students have to pay a higher tuition when the state and county do not provide adequate funding.

review_title: Good East Job for College Students
pros: Working as a lifeguard comes with its pros. It is very low stress, there are not a lot of other candidates who can swoop in and replace you, and the perk of being able to swim when you want to are lovely.
cons: Sometimes a job that doesn't offer any challenges at all lacks the ability to inspire growth. It is very easy to get bored working a job such as this. It is not a 'resume padder' and what you get out of the experience is what you make of it. Of course not everyone is looking for a growth opportunity, but a recent graduate will quickly feel "stuck" here if they do not make an effort to pursue a career.

pros: I work in the Continue Education Department and I love how the department staff want s to help others succeed in life, no matter where they are.
cons: It would help if the school also advertised Continuing Education Department on the commercials that the school place on local networks.

review_title: Review of Suffolk County Community College
pros: Suffolk County Community College is a very interesting place in which to work. My colleagues are stimulating, I have a great deal of autonomy in how I teach my courses, and I am encouraged to grow professionally and intellectually. I highly recommend Suffolk County Community College as a place to work.
cons: There is some bureaucracy at the the college, and sometimes decisions made by the upper administration do not make so much sense.

job_title: Professional Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Good work environment.  Everyone willing to work together towards common goal
cons: Job advancement is very difficult.  Part time work is easier to come by than full time-probably due to health benefits.  Mandatory 2-week furlough for College Aides makes it tough to handle the work load when an office is short staffed.

pros: Very nice group of people to work with.  Suffolk hires some of the best professionals and cares about the student body.

pros: I'm quite happy with my current chairpersons and previous ones. The college at the Grant Campus is enjoyable and professional. At times, there are a few persons that aren't nice but that's everywhere. I do recommend SCCC to be a good university to work for. Besides following the policies and procedures you still have academic/teaching freedom, it's an institution worth your time and effort.
cons: Due to policy, the road to full time teaching is a challenge.
